content:
Ghost rockets, also known as Scandinavian ghost rockets, were rocket- or missile-shaped unidentified flying objects spotted in 1946 in Sweden and nearby countries. The first reports were made in February 1946 by Finnish observers, with around 2,000 sightings logged between May and December of that year. Radar returns verified 200 sightings, and physical fragments attributed to ghost rockets were recovered. Investigations suggested that many sightings were likely caused by meteors, although some did not align with meteor shower activity and displayed characteristics inconsistent with meteors, such as reported maneuverability.

The origins of the unidentified ghost rockets continue to be debated. In 1946, it was thought that they may have originated from the former German rocket facility at Peenemünde and were long-ra
categories: Cold War weapons of the Soviet Union

content: VE 231 Saphir was a French two-stage sounding rocket as part of the gemstones program, leading up to the Diamant orbital rocket. It was used between 1965 and 1967, with a payload capacity of 365 kilograms and a maximum altitude of 1,000 kilometres. The rocket used liquid and solid propellant, and was guided. Variants were designed to test radio-controlled guidance, inertial guidance, and warhead separation and ablative heat shielding. The Diamant rocket, developed from the Saphir, carried the first French satellite into orbit. After the successful launch of Diamant, Saphir rockets were used to test technologies for France's intercontinental ballistic missile development.

The Space Shuttle Atlantis (OV-104) is a retired orbiter belonging to NASA, manufactured by Rockwell International and delivered to the Kennedy Space Center in 1985. It completed 33 missions, with its final flight being STS-135 in July 2011. Atlantis landed for the last time on July 21, 2011, after orbiting the Earth 4,848 times and traveling nearly 126,000,000 miles. Named after a research vessel, RV Atlantis, the shuttle is now on display at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex.

content:
Space Shuttle Challenger (OV-099) was a second Space Shuttle orbiter to fly into space after Columbia. It was destroyed in a disaster in January 1986, killing all seven crew members aboard. Initially manufactured as a test article, it was pressed into operational service in the Space Shuttle program. During its three years of operation, Challenger was flown on ten missions, spending over 62 days in space and completing almost 1,000 orbits around Earth.

Challenger was used for numerous civilian satellite launches and was also used as a test bed for various space technologies. On its tenth flight in January 1986, Challenger broke up 73 seconds after liftoff, killing the seven-member crew of STS-51-L. The cause of the disaster was attributed to a failed O-ring seal in one of Challenger's solid rocket boosters. The loss of Challenger and its crew led to significant changes in the Space Shuttle program to improve crew safety. The recovered remains of the orbiter are mostly buried in a missile silo located at Cape Canaveral LC-31, though one piece is on display at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex.

content:
Space Shuttle Columbia (OV-102) was the first of five Space Shuttle orbiters to fly in space, debuting the Space Shuttle launch vehicle on April 12, 1981. It retained unique features indicative of its experimental design, including test instrumentation and distinctive black chines. Throughout its 22 years of operation, Columbia completed 28 missions, spending over 300 days in space and completing over 4,000 orbits around Earth. It was used for scientific research and historic missions, such as carrying the first female commander of an American spaceflight mission and the first Israeli astronaut.

However, at the end of its final flight in February 2003, Columbia disintegrated upon reentry, killing the seven-member crew and destroying most of the scientific payloads aboard. An investigation concluded that damage sustained during launch fatally compromised the vehicle's thermal protection system. The loss of Columbia led to changes in NASA's human exploration programs and the establishment of the Constellation program in 2005, ultimately leading to the retirement of the Space Shuttle program in 2011. Numerous memorials and dedications have been made to honor the crew, including the Columbia Memorial Space Center and the naming of the Columbia Hills on Mars' Gusev crater after the crew.

content:
Space Shuttle Discovery (OV-103) is a retired American space shuttle orbiter and was the third of five fully operational orbiters built under NASA's Space Shuttle program. It launched and landed 39 times over 27 years, making it the spacecraft with the most spaceflights to date. The shuttle's launch vehicle included a central fuel tank and two reusable solid rocket boosters, with nearly 25,000 heat-resistant tiles covering the orbiter to protect it during re-entry.

Discovery conducted its final mission, STS-133, in February 2011 and spent a total of nearly a year in space. It performed research, International Space Station assembly missions, and launched the Hubble Space Telescope into orb

content: Space Shuttle Endeavour (OV-105) is a retired orbiter from NASA's Space Shuttle program, and the last operational Shuttle built. It flew its first mission in May 1992 and its final mission in May 2011. Initially, STS-134 was planned to be the last mission, but STS-135 was later authorized by Congress. Endeavour was constructed in 1987 to replace the Challenger, using spare parts from other shuttles. It will soon be on display at the California Science Center.

content:
A sodium bicarbonate rocket, also known as an Alka-Seltzer rocket, is a model rocket made from a 35mm film canister and propelled by carbon dioxide generated from the reaction of an acid with sodium bicarbonate. It is often used in science classes to demonstrate principles of chemistry and physics.

In the experiment, water and an effervescent tablet are added to the canister, which is then sealed tightly. The pressure of the carbon dioxide causes the canister to be launched into the air with a popping sound. Various experiments and lessons can be conducted with the bicarbonate rocket, such as adjusting the amounts of water and Alka-Seltzer to propel the rocket the greatest distance or deriving equations to calculate its speed and velocity.

The experiment demonstrates Newton's third law of motion, with the chemical reaction rapidly creating gas that is expelled in one direction from the rocket engine, forcing the rocket in the opposite direction. The film canister rocket uses solid and liquid fuel to create carbon dioxide gas, which escapes out

content: The KTDU-80 is an integrated propulsion system for the Soyuz spacecraft, combining main propulsion, RCS, and attitude control. It uses UDMH and N2O4 propellants and the S5.80 engine, providing 2.95 kN of thrust with a specific impulse of 302 s. It is rated for 30 starts and has a total firing time of 890 seconds. The system weighs 310 kg and measures 1.2 m long and 2.1 m in diameter.

content: Virgin Orbit developed and operated the two-stage orbital launch vehicle LauncherOne from 2021 to 2023, following a 13-year development period. The air-launched rocket was designed to carry smallsat payloads into Sun-synchronous orbit after being air-launched from a modified Boeing 747-400. Despite early setbacks, including a failed test flight in 2020, the rocket successfully delivered payloads to low Earth orbit in three flights. However, the final flight in 2023 also failed to reach orbit. With LauncherOne being the first all liquid-fuelled air-launched orbital rocket, Virgin Orbit had originally intended for it to carry a smaller 200 kg payload before increasing its capacity to 300 kg to better target their intended market. With Virgin Orbit ceasing operations after bankruptcy in 2023, the future of LauncherOne is uncertain.

content: The SpaceX Kestrel was a LOX/RP-1 pressure-fed rocket engine developed in the 2000s for the Falcon 1 rocket's upper stage. It is no longer in production since the last Falcon 1 flight in 2009. The engine was built with a pintle architecture similar to the Merlin engine, but without a turbopump and fed only by tank pressure. It was ablatively cooled in the chamber and throat and radiatively cooled in the nozzle, made from a high-strength niobium alloy resistant to cracking. content: SuperDraco is a rocket engine designed by SpaceX for use as a launch escape system for the Dragon 2 space capsule. The engine, which is part of the Draco family, features a redundant array of eight engines and utilizes a storable hypergolic propellant that allows for firing many months after fueling. It combines the functions of a reaction control system and a main propulsive engine, providing increased reliability for spacecraft. The engine is used on crew transport flights to low Earth orbit and was also intended for use on the now-canceled Red Dragon to Mars. With a thrust capability of 73,000 newtons, the engines were throttled to 68,170

content: Antares, formerly known as Taurus II, is a launch system developed by Orbital Sciences Corporation and the Pivdenne Design Bureau to send the Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station. It is the largest rocket operated by Northrop Grumman and has the capacity to launch payloads of more than 8,000 kg into low Earth orbit. Antares made its first flight in April 2013 and has been used to launch the Cygnus spacecraft for NASA's COTS and CRS programs. The rocket suffered a catastrophic failure in 2014 but returned to flight successfully in 2016. The Antares has flown two major design iterations, the 100 series and 200 series, and is currently under development for the 300 series. Due to political tensions between Ukraine and Russia, Northrop Grumman has entered into agreements with other aerospace companies for the production of the rocket's first stage.
categories: Orbital Sciences Corporation space launch vehicles

Originally intended for the Soviet N1F Moon rocket, the NK-33A is now used on the first stage of the Soyuz-2-1v launch vehicle. When the supply of the NK-33 engines runs out, Russia will supply the new RD-193 rocket engine. content: Ares I was a crew launch vehicle developed by NASA as part of the Constellation program. It was intended to launch the Orion spacecraft for human spaceflight missions after the Space Shuttle was retired in 2011. Ares I was meant to complement the larger Ares V, which was the cargo launch vehicle for Constellation. However, the program, including Ares I, was cancelled by U.S. president Barack Obama in October 2010. NASA then detailed the Space Launch System as its new vehicle for human exploration beyond

content: The Ares V, previously known as the Cargo Launch Vehicle or CaLV, was part of the cancelled NASA Constellation program meant to replace the Space Shuttle after its retirement in 2011. Named after the Greek god of war, Ares V was designed to launch the Earth Departure Stage and Altair lunar lander for a planned return to the Moon by 2019. It was also intended to support a human presence on Mars and serve as the primary launcher for missions beyond the Earth-Moon system, including crewed missions to Mars. Ares V was to work alongside the Ares I rocket for launching the Orion spacecraft and was considered safer than the Space Shuttle, employing technologies from the A

Liberty, a launch vehicle concept proposed by Northrop Grumman Space Systems and Airbus Defence and Space, was intended for NASA's CCDev program to develop privately operated crew vehicles to low Earth orbit. Similar to the defunct Ares I project, Liberty would combine a five-segment SRB with the core stage of the European Ariane 5 as a second stage, and was intended to be launched from Kennedy Space Center. It was designed to service the International Space Station for crew and cargo, and had the potential to launch government

Atlas II was a member of the Atlas family of launch vehicles, evolving from the successful Atlas missile program of the 1950s. It was an evolution of the Atlas I, with longer first-stage tanks, higher-performing engines, and the option for strap-on solid rocket boosters. Designed to launch payloads into various orbits, 63 successful launches were carried out betwe

The Atlas III, also known as the Atlas II-AR, was an American orbital launch vehicle used from 2000 to 2005. It was based on the successful Atlas II rocket and shared many components. Unlike previous Atlas family members, it featured a "normal" staging method with a single center engine serving as the

The Atlas V is an expendable launch system, originally designed by Lockheed Martin and now operated by United Launch Alliance (ULA). It is used for DoD, NASA, and Commercial payloads and is America's longest-serving active rocket. After 87 launches, ULA announced in August 2021 that Atlas V will be retired, with 16 launches remaining as of June 2024. The rocket consists of two main stages and uses Russian engines for the first stage, and American engines for the Centaur upper stage. Strap-on solid rocket boosters are used in most configurations. content: The Common Core Booster (CCB) is the first stage of the American Atlas V rocket, designed with modularity in mind. It is 32.46 m long, 3.81 m in diameter, and powered by a single RD-180 engine burning RP-1 and liquid oxygen. Testing was conducted in the United States and Russia, with the first launch in 2002. The Atlas V has made 86 flights using the CCB. The intended use of CCBs as boosters on the Atlas V Heavy and the Japanese GX program were not developed or cancelled, respectively.

Atlas is a family of US missiles and space launch vehicles that originated with the SM-65 Atlas. The Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) program was initiated in the late 1950s under the Convair Division of General Dynamics. It was a liquid propellant rocket burning RP-1 kerosene fuel with liquid oxygen in three engines configured in an unusual "stage-and-a-half" design. The name Atlas was proposed by Karel Bossart and his design team at Convair to reflect the missile's position as the biggest and most powerful at the time, as well as the parent company of Convair, the Atlas Corporation.

The missiles saw brief ICBM service, but from 1962-1963, Atlas boosters launched the first four US astronauts to orbit the Earth. The Atlas-Agena and Atlas-Centaur satellite launch vehicles were derived from the original Atlas. The Atlas-Centaur evolved into the Atlas II, with various mode
categories: United Launch Alliance space launch vehicles

content: The SM-65 Atlas was the United States' first operational intercontinental ballistic missile, developed by the Convair Division of General Dynamics. Development began in 1946 and faced multiple cancellations and re-starts before becoming a crash project in late 1952 due to the escalating Cold War and intelligence showing Soviet ICBM development. The first test launch in June 1957 failed, but the successful launch of the Soviet R-7 Semyorka in August created new urgency. Despite reliability issues with the first models, the Atlas C was declared operational in September 1959. Atlas was seen as a last-ditch weapon to counter a Soviet sneak attack on US bomber bases, but new designs, like the Minuteman, made it obsolete for ICBM use by 1965. However, it continued to have a successful history as a space launch vehicle, launching Project Mercury astronauts and becoming the foundation for a family of space launch vehicles. The Atlas Centaur line was acquired by the United Launch Alliance, which continues to support the larger Atlas V. Retired Atlas ICBMs were also refurbished and used to launch satellites until 1995.
categories: Cold War nuclear missiles of the United States
Intercontinental ballistic missiles of the United States

Unlike later versions, it did not have a stage and a half design and had fixed booster engines without a sustainer engine. It used an early version of Rocketdyne MA-1 engines producing 135,000 pounds of thrust. The A-series had several missing or partially implemented hardware compared to operational Atlases, with a powered flight lasting about two minutes and long pad hold-down times. content: The SM-65D Atlas, or Atlas D, was the first operational version of the U.S. Atlas missile. Initially used as an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), it later became a launch vehicle for low Earth orbit and beyond. The D-series Atlas was launched from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station and Vandenberg Air Force Base. It incorporated design changes from previous models and featured the full-up Rocketdyne MA-2 propulsion system with 360,000 pounds-force of thrust. Most space launcher variants of the Atlas were based on the Atlas D.

content: The SM-65E Atlas, or Atlas-E, was an operational variant of the Atlas missile, deployed as an operational ICBM from September 1961 to April 1966. After retirement, it was refurbished for orbital launches as the Atlas E/F, with the last launch conducted on March 24, 1995. The Atlas E and F had upgraded engines and ignition systems compared to the Atlas D, with separate gas generators for booster engines and a mechanism for immediate missile release as thrust built up. Atlas-E launches were conducted from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station and Vandenberg Air Force Base.

content: The Atlas-F was the last operational variant of the Atlas missile, used as an ICBM from 1961 to 1966 before being refurbished for orbital launches as the Atlas E/F. It differed from the Atlas E in its vertical silo with an elevator, and utilized the MA-3 propulsion system with a total thrust of 375,000 pounds-force. The ARMA inertial guidance system was also used, with minor differences between the E and F versions. Refurbished Atlas F space launches often used solid-fueled upper stages, with the last launch in 1981 placing a NOAA weather satellite into orbit. These space launchers were extensively rebuilt by Convair, with the ARMA system replaced with the GE Mod II guidance system.

content: The Common Booster Core (CBC) was a rocket stage used on the Delta IV rocket. It was 40.8 meters long, 5.1 meters in diameter, and powered by a single RS-68 engine burning liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. The first static test-firing was in March 2001, and the first launch was in November 2002. The Delta IV Heavy, featuring three CBCs, had a malfunction on its first flight but improvements were made. In total, the Delta IV made 45 flights before retiring in 2024, with a total of 77 CBCs launched. The CBCs were manufactured in Alabama and transported to launch sites for integration with the spacecraft and other components.

Delta II, originally designed by McDonnell Douglas, was an expendable launch system that entered service in 1989. It was part of the Delta rocket family and flew notable payloads such as GPS Block II satellites, NASA payloads, and Iridium communication satellites. Its final mission, ICESat-2, took place on 15 September 2018, marking a streak of 100 successful missions in a row. The rocket's development led to the unsuccessful Delta III and the more successful Delta IV.
categories: Boeing spacecraft and space launch systems

content: Delta III was a launch vehicle developed by McDonnell Douglas to meet the demand for larger satellites. It was intended to carry up to 3,810 kg to geostationary transfer orbit, twice the payload of its predecessor, the Delta II. However, of its three flights, the first two were failures and the third had a partially successful outcome. The program was cancelled in 2003, and Boeing shifted focus to the more capable Delta IV rocket. Multiple Delta III rockets were cannibalized for parts for other rockets.

content: The Delta IV was a group of five expendable launch systems in the Delta rocket family, primarily used for US military payloads. It flew 45 missions from 2002 to 2024 and had two main versions, the Medium and Heavy. The final flights of both occurred in 2019 and 2024, respectively. The rockets were built in Alabama and assembled at launch sites in Cape Canaveral and Vandenberg Space Force Base by United Launch Alliance.

content: Delta IV Heavy (Delta 9250H) was an expendable heavy-lift launch vehicle, the largest in the Delta IV family, retired in 2024. It was the world's third highest-capacity launch vehicle, behind NASA's Space Launch System and SpaceX's Falcon Heavy. Manufactured by United Launch Alliance (ULA), its final flight was on 9 April 2024. The first stage consisted of a central Common Booster Core (CBC) with two additional CBCs as liquid rocket boosters. All three rocket engines would operate at full thrust at lift-off, with the central engine throttling down to 55% after 44 seconds to conserve fuel until the other two engines separate. The central engine would then throttle back up to full thrust after the other engines burn out at 242 seconds. The

content: Ariane is a European series of expendable launch vehicles for space use, named after the mythological character Ariadne. Proposed by France in 1973 and agreed upon by France, Germany, and the UK, it was Western Europe's second attempt at developing its own launcher. The project was code-named L3S. Airbus Defence and Space is responsible for development and testing, while Arianespace, a commercial subsidiary, handles production, operations,

Atlas is a family of US missiles and space launch vehicles that originated with the SM-65 Atlas, a liquid propellant rocket burning RP-1 kerosene fuel with liquid oxygen in three engines. It had an unusual "stage-and-a-half" design with outboard booster engines jettisoned during ascent and a center sustainer engine remaining connected through propellant depletion.

The name "Atlas" was proposed by Karel Bossart and his design team at Convair on project MX-1593, reflecting the missile's status as the biggest and most powerful at the time, as well as the parent company of Convair, the Atlas Corporation.

While the missiles had brief ICBM service, they also launched the first US astronauts to orbit the Earth and were the basis for other satellite launch vehicles. The various models of Atlas were launched numerous times between 1991 and 2005, with the Atlas V still in service and launches

content: The Minotaur is a family of US solid fuel launch vehicles converted from retired Minuteman and Peacekeeper intercontinental ballistic missiles by Northrop Grumman for the Space Force's Rocket Systems Launch Program. Three variants are in service: Minotaur I for small satellite launches into low Earth orbit, Minotaur II (Chimera) as a target launch vehicle for suborbital flights, and Minotaur IV for more capable LEO launches. The Minotaur V is designed for higher orbits, and the Minotaur III is under development for suborbital flights. The Minotaur I and II are derived from the Mi

The Molniya (Russian: Молния, meaning "lightning"), GRAU Index 8K78, was a modification of the R-7 Semyorka rocket with four stages. It was named after the Molniya communication satellites it launched. Developed as a booster for planetary probes, it had a larger third stage and a fourth stage (Blok L) for in-orbit payload delivery. However, rushed development led to malfunctions, and it was replaced by the improved Molniya (M) in 1964. Despite this, the 8K78 continued flying until 1967.
categories: Space launch vehicles of the Soviet Union

content: The Molniya-M, also known as Молния, was a Soviet Union (later Russian) launch vehicle derived from the R-7 Semyorka Intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). The original 8K78 booster faced numerous launch failures, prompting improvements to the core and strap-on engines, as well as a redesign of the Blok I stage. The 8K78M was first launched in 1964, and it made a total of 297 launches with 21 failures. The final flight of a Molniya-M occurred on September 30, 2010, and it was eventually replaced by the Soyuz-2/Fregat. While initially developed for planetary probes, the Molniya-M was later used to launch Molniya and Oko satellites into orbits with high eccentricity.
categories: Space launch vehicles of the Soviet Union

content: The Polyot, also known as Sputnik, was an interim orbital carrier rocket used to test ASAT spacecraft. content: Soyuz is a family of Russian and Soviet carrier rockets developed by OKB-1 and manufactured by Progress Rocket Space Centre in Samara, Russia. It is the rocket with the most launches in the history of spaceflight and was the only launch vehicle approved for transporting astronauts to the International Space Station between 2011 and 2020. Soyuz rockets are used to launch crewed Soyuz spacecraft, uncrewed Progress supply spacecraft, and for commercial launches marketed and operated by Starsem and Arianespace. Al
categories: Space launch vehicles of the Soviet Union

content: Soyuz-2 is an updated version of the Soviet Soyuz rocket, featuring improved engines and digital flight control. It is a three-stage launch vehicle used for placing payloads into low Earth orbit. This rocket is often flown with an upper stage for lifting payloads into higher orbits. The NPO Lavochkin-manufactured Fregat is the most commonly used upper stage. Soyuz-2 rockets were first launched from Baikonur Cosmodrome and Plesetsk Cosmodrome, and have also been launched from the Centre Spatial Guyanais (CSG). In 2016, the Vostochny Cosmodrome began operating Soyuz-2 flights from its first launch pad. Soyuz-2 has replaced the Molniya-M, Soyuz-U, and Soyuz-FG rockets since 2010, 2017, and 2019, respectively. Production of Soyuz-U rockets was halted in April 2015, and the final flight took place in 2017, carrying Progress MS-05 to the International Space Station (ISS).

content: The Soyuz-2.1v, also known as the Union 2.1v, is a modified Russian expendable launch vehicle derived from the Soyuz-2.1b and part of the R-7 rocket family. It is produced by TsSKB Progress in Samara, Russia, and launches from facilities at the Plesetsk Cosmodrome in Northwest Russia

content: The Soyuz-FG launch vehicle, an improved version of the Soyuz-U from the R-7 family of rockets, was designed and constructed by TsSKB-Progress in Samara, Russia, with guidance, navigation, and control system developed by "Polisvit" Special Design Bureau in Ukraine. It made its maiden flight on 20 May 2001, carrying a Progress cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS), and was retired after the 25 September 2019 launch of Soyuz MS-15. From 30 October 2002 to 25 September 2019, it was the only vehicle used by the Russian Federal Space Agency to launch crewed spacecraft to the ISS. For uncrewed flights, it optionally flew with a Fregat upper stage, with launches marketed by Starsem. The Soyuz-FG was launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan and performed 64 successful launches until its first failu

content: The Soyuz-U2 (GRAU index 11A511U2) was a Soviet and Russian carrier rocket, part of the R-7 family. It featured increased performance compared to the baseline Soyuz-U due to the use of syntin propellant. This allowed for heavier spacecraft to be launched and lighter spacecraft to be placed in higher orbits. However, in 1996, it was retired due to the additional cost of production not justifying the performance advantage. The final flight, Soyuz TM-22, occurred on 3 September 1995. The Soyuz-U2 launched four Zenit reconnaissance satellites, crewed Soyuz spacecraft to space stations Salyut 7 and Mir, and supplied Progress cargo spacecraft. It also had missions with the Gamm

content: The Voskhod rocket, a derivative of the Soviet R-7 ICBM, was initially designed for human spaceflight but later used for launching Zenit reconnaissance satellites. It consisted of the Molniya 8K78M third stage minus the Blok L. In 1966, all R-7 variants were upgraded with the core stage and strap-ons of the Soyuz 11A511. The Blok I stage in the Voskhod booster used the RD-0107 engine, except for the two crewed Voskhod launches, which had RD-0108 engines. Four of the launches resulted in failures. It had live second and fourth stages, and an improved first stage using an Algol 1B. NASA asked Lockheed Missiles and Space, McDonnell Douglas, and TRW to conduct a ten-month study, resulting in a proposal for a series of launch vehicles centered around the Space Transportation Main Engine (STME) liquid-fuel rocket engine. The largest proposed vehicle, NLS-1, would have used a modified Space Shuttle external tank as its core stage with four STMEs attached. Period illustrations show that even large

content: The Shuttle-C was a NASA study to convert the Space Shuttle launch stack into an uncrewed cargo launcher. It would use Shuttle external tank and Solid Rocket Boosters with a cargo module instead of the orbiter. The concept aimed to reduce costs by reusing shuttle technology and hardware. After the Challenger incident, the Shuttle-C was considered for its potential to support a higher flight rate due to lower maintenance and safety requirements. It was planned to be the main crew launch vehicle for the International Lunar Resources Exploration Program and was even considered for a crewed mission to Mars in the early 1990s. The concept has been studied since the 1970s and was discussed in Gerard O'Neill's "The High Frontier: Human Colonies in Space."

content: The Space Launch System (SLS) is a super heavy-lift expendable launch vehicle used by NASA for the Artemis Moon landing program. It is designed to launch the crewed Orion spacecraft on a trans-lunar trajectory. The uncrewed Artemis 1, the first SLS launch, took place on November 16, 2022. Development of the SLS began in 2011 to replace the retired Space Shuttle and the cancelled Ares I and Ares V launch vehicles. The SLS reuses hardware from the Shuttle program, including the solid rocket boosters and RS-25 first stage engines. content: The Thor-Ablestar, also known as Thor-Epsilon, was an early American expendable launch system with a PGM-17 Thor missile and an Ablestar upper stage. The Ablestar second stage was an enlarged version of the Able, increasing payload capacity and incorporating restart capabilities. Two versions were built, with launches occurring from Cape Canaveral and Vandenberg Space Force Base. The development of the stage took eight months, making it the first rocket with such a capability.

content: The Thor-Delta, also known as Delta DM-19, was an early American expendable launch system used for 12 orbital launches in the early 1960s. It was a member of the Thor family of rockets and the first member of the Delta family, with the first stage being a Thor missile in the DM-19 configuration and the second stage being the Delta, derived from the earlier Able stage. It featured a cold gas attitude control system, allowing it to be stabilized in orbit for restart and more precise burns. The Thor-Delta was the first rocket to use the combination of a Thor missile and a Delta upper stage, and this configuration was reused for many later rockets. Baikonur Site 31, also called Site 31/6, is a launch site at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan. It is used for launching derivatives of the R-7 Semyorka missile and has become the primary launch site for Soyuz flights to the International Space Station since 2020. It took over from Site 1/5 (Gagarin's Start) due to lack of funding for modernization. Before that, it saw only a few crewed flights when Site 1/5 w

Site 45 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome was once a Zenit rocket launch site with two pads, now inactive. It hosted Soviet and Russian government launches, as well as commercial launches for Globalstar under the Land Launch program. Pad 1 was completed in 1983 and the first launch failed in 1985, but subsequent launches were successful. Pad 2, completed in 1990, was destroyed by a launch failure in the same year and was not rebuilt.

In 2017, the last Zenit-3F was launched from Site 45, and plans were made to rebuild the launch pad to support the new domestic Irtysh launch vehicle. However, in 2023, the Baiterek joint venture filed a claim against Roscosmos for failing to conduct an environmental impact assessment, effectively ending the Baiterek project and the development of the Irtysh launch vehicle scheduled to start from Site 45 in 2024.

content:
Cape Canaveral Space Force Station (CCSFS) is the primary launch site for the United States Space Force's Eastern Range. It is located on Cape Canaveral in Brevard County, Florida and is part of Space Launch Delta 45, headquartered at the nearby Patrick Space Force Base. The station has three active launch pads and a 10,000-foot runway for military airlift aircraft.

CCSFS has a rich history in American space exploration, launching numerous pioneering missions including the first U.S. Earth satellite, first U.S. astronaut, first U.S. astronaut in orbit, and the first spacecraft to leave the Solar System. Portions of the base have been designated a National Historic Landmark.

The facility has undergone several name changes over the years, including Cape Canaveral Launch Area, LRPG Launching Area, Cape Canaveral Auxiliary Air Force Base, and Cape Canaveral Missile Test Annex. It was later known as Cape Kennedy Air Force Station and Cape Canaveral Air Force Station before being renamed "Cape Canaveral Space Force Station" in December 2020.

content: A rocket-propelled grenade (RPG) is a shoulder-fired weapon that launches rockets with explosive warheads, often used against tanks. They can be reloaded with new grenades and are stabilized in flight with fins. The high-explosive anti-tank (HEAT) warheads are effective against lightly armored vehicles, but modern heavily-armored vehicles are generally too well-protected to be penetrated, though they can still cause secondary damage to vulnerable systems. The term "rocket-propelled grenade" comes from the Russian acronym for "handheld anti-tank grenade launcher."

content: The Apollo Lunar Module (LM /ˈlɛm/) was a spacecraft used during the United States' Apollo program to transport astronauts between lunar orbit and the Moon's surface. It was the first crewed spacecraft to operate in the vacuum of space and remains the only crewed vehicle to land anywhere beyond Earth. Due to its inability to fly through Earth's atmosphere, the LM was ferried to lunar orbit attached to the Apollo command and service module (CSM). Ten lunar modules were launched into space, with six of them landing on the Moon from 1969 to 1972. The first two were tests in low Earth orbit, while the third was a test in low lunar orbit. The Apollo 13 lunar module served as a lifeboat to keep the crew alive after their CSM was disabled by an oxygen tank explosion en route to the Moon. The six landed descent stages remain at their landing sites, while their corresponding ascent stages crashed into the Moon. One ascent stage was discarded in a heliocentric orbit, and the remaining three LMs were burned up in the Earth's atmosphere. The development of the LM was overseen by Grumman and was plagued with problems that caused delays. Despite this

content: Armadillo Aerospace, a startup in Mesquite, Texas, aimed to create a crewed suborbital spacecraft for space tourism and had long-term hopes for orbital spaceflight. Founded by John Carmack, the company won $350,000 in 2008 and $500,000 in 2009 for the Northrop Grumman Lunar Lander Challenge. In 2010, they partnered with Space Adventures for suborbital rocket tourist flights. But setbacks, including a 2013 crash, led to the company being put on hold. In 2014, former employees formed Exos Aerospace and acquired Armadillo's assets. In 2018, Exos launched the Suborbital Active Rocket with Guidance (SARGE) from New Mexico. Carmack hinted at a potential comeback for Armadillo Aerospace in 2017, suggesting his own future plans could include reviving the company.

content:
Project Morpheus, a NASA initiative that began in 2010, aimed to develop a vertical takeoff and landing test vehicle known as the Morpheus Lander. The project focused on showcasing a new nontoxic spacecraft propellant system using methane and oxygen, as well as autonomous landing and hazard detection technology. The lander's prototype was designed for autonomous flight, including vertical takeoff and landings, and has the capability to transport 1,100 pounds of cargo on the Moon.

The Alpha prototype lander, about 12 feet in diameter and weighing approximately 2,400 pounds, was built at NASA's Johnson Space Center and Armadillo Aerospace's facility near Dallas. The project utilized "lean development" engineering practices to save time and costs, with activities including ground and flight operations, range safety, and software development.

By 2015, the Morpheus project had saved an estimated $50 million through streamlined processes, minimized documentation, and purchasing parts from commercial suppliers. The project concluded with six formal documents and the return of the lander to JSC.

The RVT project, conducted by JAXA from 1998 to 2003, involved the testing of reusable rockets, resulting in the development of four experimental vehicles that tackled technical challenges for future Reusable Launch Vehicles (RLV). Ground and flight tests took place at the ISAS Noshiro Rocket Testing Center. JAXA proposed to develop a reusable high-altitude rocket using RVT technologies, capable of carrying a 100 kg payload to an altitude of 100 km. The rocket, with equipment derived from RVT, is expected to cost 50 billion yen to develop and be capable of five flights per day at a cost of 10,000 yen per flight. Experimental payloads will be recovered after the flight, reducing costs for payload developers, and the vehicle will have the capability to stop and hover at any altitude

content: Rotary Rocket Company developed the fully reusable single-stage-to-orbit (SSTO) Roton spacecraft concept in the late 1990s. The idea was conceived by Bevin McKinney and shared with Gary Hudson. The company raised venture capital, opened a factory in Mojave, California, and partnered with Scaled Composites to build the fuselage. They conducted three hover flights in 1999, but closed in early 2001 after exhausting funds. The concept originated from McKinney's idea of using helicopter blades for a launch vehicle and gained funding from billionaire Walt Anderson and Tom Clancy, allowing the company to launch in October 1996.

subcategories: Black Sky: The Race for Space

content: SpaceX is developing the Starship, a two-stage super heavy-lift launch vehicle, aiming to significantly reduce launch costs through reusability, increased payload mass, and mass manufacturing. The spacecraft and booster feature Raptor engines burning liquid methane and liquid oxygen, made from a stainless steel alloy. The spacecraft can re-enter the atmosphere and perform a 'belly flop' maneuver, while lunar and depot variants do not require a thermal protection system. The development involves test flights that often result in the destruction of the prototype vehicles. As a successor to Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy rockets, Starship will support various space missions and rely on orbital refueling for farther destinations. The Starship HLS variant will also land astronauts on the Moon as part of the Artemis program. SpaceX plans to deploy its second-generation Starlink satellite constellation using Starship. A ship-to-ship propellant transfer demonstration is expected in 2025 to prove out this critical capability.

content:
Starship HLS, a lunar lander from SpaceX, is designed to transport astronauts from lunar orbit to the Moon's surface and back as part of NASA's Artemis program. It will launch from Earth on a Starship rocket and be refueled in orbit before heading to a lunar near-rectilinear halo orbit (NRHO). There, it will rendezvous with a crewed Orion spacecraft launched from Earth by NASA's Space Launch System. Two astronauts will transfer from Orion to HLS for a 7-day mission with at least five EVAs before returning to Orion in NRHO.

content: Blackstar is the reported code-name of a secret US orbital spaceplane system. The existence of the program was reported in March 2006 by Aviation Week & Space Technology magazine, stating it had been underway since the early 1990s. The impetus for Blackstar was to allow the US government to retain orbital reconnaissance capabilities jeopardized after the 1986 Challenger disaster. The United States Air Force's Space Command was reportedly unaware of Blackstar, suggesting it was operated by an intelligence agency such as the National Reconnaissance Office. Aviation Week speculated that the s

It used the expendable Energia rocket, a super heavy-lift launch vehicle. "Buran" refers to both the shuttle orbiter and the entire spaceplane project, inc
categories: Spacecraft launched by Zenit and Energia rockets

content: The Buran programme, also known as the VKK Space Orbiter programme, was a Soviet and later Russian reusable spacecraft project that began in 1974 and was formally suspended in 1993. The programme included the development and launch of the Buran-class orbiters, with orbiter 1K completing one uncrewed spaceflight in 1988. The project was a response to the US Space Shuttle program and benefited from extensive espionage undertaken by the KGB, resulting in many similarities between American and Soviet Shuttle designs. The Buran-class orbiters used the expendable Energia rocket as a launch vehicle and had the capability of flying uncrewed missions and performing fully automated landings. The project was the largest and most expensive in the history of Soviet space exploration.

The Heinkel He 176 was the first ever rocket-powered aircraft, debuting on June 20, 1939. It was built by the Heinkel company as part of a focus on high-speed flight technology. The compact and wooden aircraft had a reclined seating position for the pilot and a unique jettisonable nose escape system. Despite being cancelled in 1939 due to its small size and performance, the He 176 proved the concept of rocket propulsion and high-speed flight. Lessons learned from the project were used in subsequent aircraft such as the Heinkel He 280 and the Messerschmitt Me 163. Most documentation and the prototype were destroyed during the war, but some material may have ended up in Soviet/Russian archives. Only two pictures of the He 176 have survived. The often-quoted performance data, such as its speed of 750 km/h or 800 km/h, is based on anecdotal evidence and not on sound documents.

content:
The Messerschmitt Me 163 Komet is a rocket-powered interceptor aircraft designed and produced by Messerschmitt. It is the only operational rocket-powered fighter aircraft in history and the first piloted aircraft to exceed 1,000 km/h in level flight.

Development of the Me 163 can be traced back to 1937 and the work of Alexander Lippisch and DFS. Plans for a propeller-powered aircraft were dropped in favor of rocket propulsion. The prototype performed its maiden flight on September 1, 1941, impressing German officials and leading to plans for widespread introduction.

In July 1944, test pilot Heini Dittmar reached a speed of 1,130 km/h, an unofficial airspeed record until 1953. The Me 163 began flying operational missions in 1944, defending against enemy bombing raids. Germany provided design schematics and a single Me 163 to Japan, leading to the development of the Mitsubishi J8M. By the end of the conflict, roughly 370 Komets had been completed, most of which were being used operationally.

The Me 163 was credited with the destruction of between 9 and 18 Allied aircraft against 10 losses. Many Me 163 pilots were killed during testing and training flights, partly due to the high volatility and hazard of the rocket propellant. Besides Nazi Germany, no nation ever made operational use of the Me 163, with the only other operational rocket-powered aircraft being the Japanese Yokosuka MXY-7 Ohka.

content:
The Miles M.52 was a turbojet-powered supersonic research aircraft project in the UK in the 1940s. Miles Aircraft received a contract in 1943 to produce an aircraft capable of reaching at least 1,000 mph (1,600 km/h) during level flight. The programme was ambitious and involved cutting-edge aerodynamic research and innovative design work.

Secrecy surrounded the project until 1945, when the Labour government terminated it in 1946 due to budgetary reasons and skepticism regarding the practicality of supersonic aircraft. The decision was criticized, and the Ministry of Supply controversially investigated the design with scaled-down unmanned models using different wing and control surface configurations. The contract was awarded to Vickers instead of Miles.

Despite the decision to end the M.52 programme, a model with the M52 configuration achieved Mach 1.38 in controlled supersonic level flight, providing some validation of the aerodynamics. Work on the afterburning version of the Power Jets W.B.2/700 turbojet was also cancelled. Miles shared the research and design with Bell Aircra

content: The Saunders-Roe SR.53 was a prototype interceptor aircraft developed in the 1950s for the RAF. It used both jet and rocket propulsion to rapidly climb and approach enemy bombers, then return to base using jet power. Although it showed promise in test flights, advances in surface-to-air missile technology made the aircraft obsolete. The development programme was cancelled in 1960 after 56 test flights. Two prototypes were built, one of which is now on display at the RAF Museum Cosford.
categories: Cancelled military aircraft projects of the United Kingdom

content: The Saunders-Roe SR.177 was a 1950s project to develop a combined jet- and rocket-powered interceptor aircraft for the RAF and Royal Navy. It was based on the experimental SR.53 but had a nose-mounted radar and more powerful engine. The German Navy also expressed interest in the project, but it was ultimately cancelled in 1957 due to changes in military policies. A larger derivative, the SR.187, was also studied but was cancelled the same year. Despite some interest, including from Japan, the project was never revived and the prototypes were eventually broken up.
categories: Cancelled military aircraft projects of the United Kingdom

content: Skylon, designed by Reaction Engines Limited, is a reusable single-stage-to-orbit spaceplane concept that uses the revolutionary SABRE propulsion system. The aircraft is designed to take off from a reinforced runway and reach Mach 5.4 at 26 kilometers altitude, using the atmosphere's oxygen before switching to internal liquid oxygen to achieve Mach 25 for orbit. It can carry 17 tonnes of cargo to low Earth orbit, 11 tonnes to the International Space Station, and 7.3 tonnes to Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit. The vehicle would re-enter the atmosphere and land on a runway, undergo maintenance with a turnaround time of two days, and complete at least 200 orbital flights per vehicle. Testing of key technologies was successfully completed in 2012, allowing the project to advance to a development phase. Groundworks for an engine test facility have been completed, with plans for ground-based engine tests to begin in 2021 and uncrewed test flights by 2025. The projected cost per kilogram (kg) of payload to LEO is estimated to be reduced from the current £1,108/kg to £650/kg, with further cost reduction over time. The lifetime cost of the program was estimated to be about $12 billion in 2004, with public funding beginning in 2009, and the British government pledging £60 million to the project in 2013.

The Convair XGAM-71 Buck Duck was an air-launched decoy missile developed by Convair in the early 1950s to disrupt enemy air defenses and protect incoming bomber fleets. Convair received a development contract from the US Air Force in 1954, and the project was designated GAM-71 when put into production.

The missile was designed to have the same radar signature as the B-36 bomber and was intended to be carried in the bomb bays of the B-36. The small size of the GAM-71 allowed it to fit in the bomber's bomb bay, and it carried internal radar reflectors to mimic the B-36's radar cross-section. Glide tests of XGAM-71 prototypes began in 1955 using a modified B-29 Superfortress as the mothership, but the program was delayed due to funding issues and higher priorities for Convair.

content: The Zero Emission Hyper Sonic Transport (ZEHST) is a hypersonic passenger jet project by EADS and JAXA. It was unveiled in 2011 and is designed to reach a maximum speed of Mach 4.5 using three different types of engines. It is projected to carry 50-100 passengers at high altitudes for greater efficiency, similar to the retired Concorde. The ZEHST is expected to fly between Paris and Tokyo in 2.5 hours and between New York and London in one hour. EADS has predicted that it could be flying by 2050.

Amateur rocketry is a hobby where enthusiasts experiment with fuels to make their own rocket motors and launch various types of rockets. This has led to research into hybrid rocket motors and the developmen

An apogee kick motor (AKM) is a rocket motor used on satellites to provide the final push to change their orbit from a transfer orbit to a circular one. It is typically used for satellites launched into geostationary orbit. After launch, the satellite is placed in a transfer orbit with a non-zero inclination, and the AKM is used to transform this orbit into a circular one at the highest point, known as the apogee. This process, called an "apogee kick", brings the inclination to around zero degrees, allowing the satellite to enter a geostationary orbit. The efficiency of the AKM maneuver directly affects the amount of fuel carried on board, as fuel expenditure in this maneuver is significant. Most geostationary satellites have about half of their initial mass left after the apogee kick maneuver, with the other half being fuel expended.

A Crawford burner, also known as a strand burner, is a device used to test the burn rate of solid propellants in chemistry. It consists of a small pressure vessel with a bar of propellant mounted on a stand. The propellant is coated to restrict the burning cross-sectional surface and ignited at one end. Wires embedded in the propellant send off electrical signals as it burns, which are recorded at different time intervals to measure the burning rate.

content: A hybrid-propellant rocket uses rocket propellants in two different phases, with one being solid and the other gas or liquid. The concept dates back to the 1930s and offers advantages over solid and liquid rockets, such as safer propellant handling and lower mechanical complexity. Hybrid rockets are more fail-safe than other types, and their thrust is easily controllable. They offer higher theoretical specific impulse (Isp) than solid rockets but lower than liquid engines, with measurements as high as 400 s using metalized fuels. While more complex than solid rockets, hybrid

Kinetic bombardment is the concept of attacking a planetary surface with inert kinetic projectiles from orbit, using the destructive power of their high-speed impact. This tactic, originating during the Cold War, typically involves a satellite with tungsten rods and a directional thrust system. When ordered, a rod is launched into a suborbital trajectory toward the target, designed to minimize air resistance for maximum impact velocity.

Flight safety in rocketry involves monitoring and enforcing strict guidelines for rocket construction and operations to protect people and infrastructure. Governments have regulations for launch vehicles and ground systems, with exclusion zones for air and sea traffic before launches. Contingency procedures are in place for malfunctioning vehicles, usually commanded by a range safety officer to terminate the mission using explosives or an autonomous computer unit on the rocket.

content: The Reaction Research Society, established in 1943, is the oldest amateur experimental rocket group in the US. Originally called the Southern California Rocket Society and then the Glendale Rocket Society, it became the Reaction Research Society in 1946 to cover various aspects of propulsion. content: The Rocket Festival, also known as Bun Bang Fai, is a traditional ceremony practiced by ethnic Lao people at the start of the wet season in Northeastern Thailand and Laos. The festivities feature music, dance, and competitive processions of floats, dancers, and musicians, culminating in the firing of homemade rockets. The festival is celebrated in various villages and municipalities, with programs and special local patterns, and is also popular in neighboring areas like Narathiwat. Local participants and sponsors use the festival to enhance their social prestige, as is customary in traditional Buddhist folk festivals throughout Southeast Asia.

content: Gaetano Arturo Crocco (26 October 1877 – 19 January 1968) was an Italian scientist and aeronautics pioneer. He founded the Italian Rocket Society and became Italy's leading space scientist. Born in Naples, he began working with solid-propellant rockets in 1927 and designed the first liquid-propellant rocket motors in Italy in 1929.
